row.name: UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABANDONED#
row.xui:
<dynradiogroup enabled="1" fill="b" focus="0" id="UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABANDONEDs.00" nl="1" quotes="" text="Remove abandoned" tooltip="A database connection pool creates and manages a pool of connections to a database. Recycling and reusing already existing connections to a database is more efficient than opening a new connection. There is one problem with connection pooling. A web application has to explicitly close ResultSet's, Statement's, and Connection's. Failure of a web application to close these resources can result in them never being available again for reuse, a database connection pool "leak". This can eventually result in your web application database connections failing if there are no more available connections. There is a solution to this problem. The Apache Commons DB connection pooling (DBCP) can be configured to track and recover these abandoned database connections. Not only can it recover them, but also generate a stack trace for the code which opened these resources and never closed them. Set this parameter to yes to configure a DB connection pool DataSource so that abandoned database connections are removed and recycled. This parameter adds the option removeAbandoned="..." to your datasource definition. See http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-7.0-doc/jndi-datasource-examples-howto.html#Preventing_database_connection_pool_leaks for more details." alt="1" required="0"><properties><entry listparam="C" name="reference" reftype="STATIC">PCK.ITPA_SHARED.PRV.VARA.YES_NO</entry><entry name="text">Remove abandoned</entry><entry name="quotes"/><entry name="id">UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABANDONEDs.00</entry><entry name="enabled">0</entry><entry name="focus">0</entry><entry name="tooltip">A database connection pool creates and manages a pool of connections to a database. Recycling and reusing already existing connections to a database is more efficient than opening a new connection. There is one problem with connection pooling. A web application has to explicitly close ResultSet's, Statement's, and Connection's. Failure of a web application to close these resources can result in them never being available again for reuse, a database connection pool "leak". This can eventually result in your web application database connections failing if there are no more available connections. There is a solution to this problem. The Apache Commons DB connection pooling (DBCP) can be configured to track and recover these abandoned database connections. Not only can it recover them, but also generate a stack trace for the code which opened these resources and never closed them.
Set this parameter to yes to configure a DB connection pool DataSource so that abandoned database connections are removed and recycled. This parameter adds the option removeAbandoned="..." to your datasource definition. See http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-7.0-doc/jndi-datasource-examples-howto.html#Preventing_database_connection_pool_leaks for more details.</entry><entry name="customfield"/><entry name="modifiable">1</entry><entry name="initvalue"/><entry name="xmlkey"/><entry name="xmlpath"/></properties></dynradiogroup>

row.name: UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABND_TIMEOUT#
row.xui: <integer enabled="1" fill="b" focus="0" id="UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABND_TIMEOUTs.00" max="" min="" nl="1" text="Remove abandoned timeout" tooltip="Use this attribute to set the number of seconds a database connection has been idle before it is considered abandoned. This adds the parameter removeAbandonedTimeout="..." to your datasource definition." alt="1"><properties><entry listparam="C" name="reference" reftype="STATIC">UC_DATATYPE_NUMERIC</entry><entry name="text">Remove abandoned timeout</entry><entry name="min"/><entry name="max"/><entry name="quotes"/><entry name="id">UC4RB_TC_REMOVE_ABND_TIMEOUTs.00</entry><entry name="enabled">0</entry><entry name="focus">0</entry><entry name="tooltip">Use this attribute to set the number of seconds a database connection has been idle before it is considered abandoned. This adds the parameter removeAbandonedTimeout="..." to your datasource definition.</entry><entry name="customfield"/><entry name="modifiable">1</entry><entry name="initvalue">0</entry></properties></integer>

This parameter adds the option logAbandoned="..." to your datasource definition." alt="1" required="0"><properties><entry listparam="C" name="reference" reftype="STATIC">PCK.ITPA_SHARED.PRV.VARA.YES_NO</entry><entry name="text">Log abandoned</entry><entry name="quotes"/><entry name="id">UC4RB_TC_LOG_ABANDONEDs.00</entry><entry name="enabled">0</entry><entry name="focus">0</entry><entry name="tooltip">Set it to yes if you want DBCP to log a stack trace of the code which abandoned the database connection resources.
